title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement cnxifeng9819@163.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Xifeng Zhang. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Zhang X (2024). MNormTest: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing. R package version 1.1.0, https://astringency.github.io/MNormTest/, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=MNormTest, https://github.com/Astringency/MNormTest.
code: @Manual{,   title = {MNormTest: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing},   author = {Xifeng Zhang},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.1.0, https://astringency.github.io/MNormTest/, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=MNormTest},   url = {https://github.com/Astringency/MNormTest}, }

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: Please note MNormTest project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: MNormTest的目标是提供一套用于多元正态分布参数假设检验的函数，包括检验单个均值向量、两个均值向量、多个均值向量、单个协方差矩阵、多个协方差矩阵、同时检验均值和协方差矩阵，以及检验多元正态随机向量的独立性. 方法原理参考了高惠璇（2005, ISBN:9787301078587）的《应用多元统计分析》. objective MNormTest provide set functions hypothesis testing parameters multivariate normal distributions, including testing single mean vector, two mean vectors, multiple mean vectors, single covariance matrix, multiple covariance matrices, mean covariance matrix simultaneously, testing independence multivariate normal random vectors. methods based book “Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis” Huixuan Gao (2005, ISBN:9787301078587).

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: CRAN: 首先，您可以从CRAN安装MNormTest的发布版本: Firstly, can install released version MNormTest CRAN : GitHub: 其次，您可以从GitHub安装MNormTest的开发版本: ’s , can install development version MNormTest GitHub :
code: install.packages("MNormTest") install.packages("pak") pak::pak("Astringency/MNormTest")

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: 在使用MNormTest包之前，您需要先加载它: using MNormTest, need load :
code: library(MNormTest)

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: MNormTest提供了7个函数： MNormTest provides 7 functions: meanTest.single, meanTest.two, meanTest.multi, covTest.single, covTest.multi, meancov.Test, ind.Test.multi.

what: 均值向量检验 (Mean Vector Test)
title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: meanTest.single被用于单个多元正态总体（总体协方差阵已知和未知时）的均值向量的检验.详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. meanTest.single used testing mean vector single multivariate normal population (population covariance matrix known unknown). details, please refer documentation function. meanTest.two被用于两个多元正态总体（总体协方差阵未知相等或不等）的均值向量的检验. 在总体协方差阵不相等时，函数提供了两种处理方法将其化为单样本问题：构造配对数据（两样本量相同）Coupled和构造修正后的数据（两样本量不同）Tranformed，详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. meanTest.two used testing mean vectors two multivariate normal populations (population covariance matrices unknown equal unequal). population covariance matrices unequal, function provides two methods reduce single sample problem: constructing paired data (two samples size) Coupled constructing transformed data (two samples different sizes) Tranformed. details, please refer documentation function. meanTest.multi被用于多个多元正态总体（总体协方差阵已知且相等）的均值向量的检验，采用Wilks Λ\Lambda统计量进行检验. 但由于分布的特殊性，函数提供了两种近方法（Bartlett’s χ2\chi^2和Rao’s FF）的检验结果，并给出了Wilks Λ\Lambda统计量的实现值及其自由度（需指定full = TRUE），若您想进行精确检验，则请根据统计量的实现值和自由度自行查找临界值. 详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. meanTest.multi used testing mean vectors multiple multivariate normal populations (population covariance matrices known equal), using Wilks Λ\Lambda statistic testing. However, due special distribution, function provides test results two approximate methods (Bartlett’s χ2\chi^2 Rao’s FF) gives observed value degrees freedom Wilks Λ\Lambda statistic (need specify full = TRUE), want conduct exact test, please find critical value according observed value degrees freedom statistic. details, please refer documentation function.
code: ?meanTest.single # or ??meanTest.single ?meanTest.two # or ??meanTest.two ?meanTest.multi # or ??meanTest.multi

what: 协方差矩阵检验 (Covariance Matrix Test)
title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: covTest.single被用于单个多元正态总体（总体均值未知时）的协方差矩阵的检验. 包含了2种情况： covTest.single used testing covariance matrix single multivariate normal population (population mean unknown). function contains two cases: H0:Σ=Σ0,H1:Σ≠Σ0(Σ0 known) H_0: \Sigma = \Sigma_0, \quad H_1: \Sigma \neq \Sigma_0 (\Sigma_0 \text{ known}) H0:Σ=σ2Σ0,H1:Σ≠σ2Σ0(σ2 unknown,Σ0 known) H_0: \Sigma = \sigma^2 \Sigma_0, \quad H_1: \Sigma \neq \sigma^2 \Sigma_0 (\sigma^2 \text{ unknown}, \Sigma_0 \text{ known}) 在第二种情况中，若Σ0=\Sigma_0 = ，则检验通常称为球形检验. 您可以通过设置不同的函数参数来选择检验的类型，详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. second case, Σ0=\Sigma_0 = , test usually called sphericity test. can choose type test setting different parameters function. details, please refer documentation function. covTest.multi被用于多个多元正态总体（总体均值未知时）的协方差矩阵的检验. 详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. covTest.multi used testing covariance matrices multiple multivariate normal populations (population mean unknown). details, please refer documentation function.
code: ?covTest.single # or ??covTest.single ?covTest.multi # or ??covTest.multi

id: 均值和协方差矩阵的同时检验-mean-and-covariance-matrix-test
what: 均值和协方差矩阵的同时检验 (Mean and Covariance Matrix Test)
title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: meancov.Test被用于多个多元正态总体的均值和协方差矩阵的同时检验. 详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. meancov.Test used testing mean covariance matrices multiple multivariate normal populations simultaneously. details, please refer documentation function.
code: ?meancov.Test # or ??meancov.Test

id: 多元正态随机向量的独立性检验-independence-test-of-multivariate-normal-random-vectors
what: 多元正态随机向量的独立性检验 (Independence Test of Multivariate Normal Random Vectors)
title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: ind.Test.multi被用于多元正态随机向量的独立性检验. 详细内容可参照函数的说明文档. ind.Test.multi used testing independence multivariate normal random vectors. details, please refer documentation function.
code: ?ind.Test.multi # or ??ind.Test.multi

title: Multivariate Normal Hypothesis Testing
text: 下面是几个简单的例子，展示了如何使用MNormTest包进行多元正态分布参数的假设检验，我们使用著名的鸢尾花数据集iris进行多总体协方阵的检验. 更多示例可以参考每个函数的说明文档. simple examples show use MNormTest test parameters multivariate normal distributions. use famous iris dataset iris test covariance matrices multiple populations. examples can found documentation function. 我们首先来看一下数据集iris的前几行: First, let’s take look first rows dataset iris: 该数据集包含了150个样品，每个样品包含5个变量：4个特征（Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width）和1个类别（Species）.为了方便后面的检验，我们将二者分开: dataset contains 150 samples, sample contains 5 variables: 4 features (Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width) 1 category (Species). convenience following tests, separate : 鸢尾花的类别有三种：setosa, versicolor, virginica. 这便是我们的三个总体（这里假设三个总体均服从四元正态分布），我们现在想要检验它们的协方差矩阵是否相等. 检验假设如下： three categories iris: setosa, versicolor, virginica. three populations (assuming three populations follow four-dimensional normal distribution), now want test whether covariance matrices equal. hypotheses follows: H0:Σ1=Σ2=Σ3,H1:Σi equal H_0: \Sigma_1 = \Sigma_2 = \Sigma_3, \quad H_1: \text{} \Sigma_i \text{ equal} 给定显著性水平α=0.05\alpha = 0.05，我们可以使用covTest.multi进行检验： Given significance level α=0.05\alpha = 0.05, can use covTest.multi testing: 如果您想输出更简洁的结果，可以设置 detail = FALSE: want concise result, can set detail = FALSE: 计算得χ2\chi^2统计量为140.94，p=0.0000<0.05=αp = 0.0000 < 0.05 = \alpha（pp值很小，在R的运算中直接算成0了），故拒绝原假设，认为在显著性水平α=0.05\alpha = 0.05下，三种鸢尾花的协方差矩阵不相等. calculated χ2\chi^2 statistic 140.94, p=0.0000<0.05=αp = 0.0000 < 0.05 = \alpha (pp small, directly calculated 0 R), reject null hypothesis conclude covariance matrices three categories iris equal significance level α=0.05\alpha = 0.05. 此外，您可以从test.iris中提取感兴趣的信息，如检验统计量的实现值、pp值、临界值和自由度: addition, can extract information interest test.iris, observed value test statistic, pp value, critical value, degrees freedom: 更多示例可以参考每个函数的说明文档. examples can found documentation function.
code: data(iris) head(iris) chart <- iris[, 1:4] species <- iris[, 5] test.iris <- covTest.multi(chart, species) test.iris <- covTest.multi(chart, species, detail = FALSE) test.iris$Stat test.iris$Df

what: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
text: Test whether mean vectors covariance matrices multiple multivariate normal populations equal simultaneously. Suppose k populations, null hypothesis "H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk Sigma1 = Sigma2 = ... = Sigmak".

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
code: meancov.Test(X, label, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
text: X data matrix matrix data frame. label vector group labels. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMeanT sample mean. SampMeanWithin sample mean group. SdTotal total sample deviation. SdWithin sample deviation group. SdWithinT sample deviation within group. Df degree freedom. sampleSize sample size group. d Modified factor statistic.

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.90-91.

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Mean and Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing (Simultaneously) — meancov.Test
code: data(iris) chart <- iris[, 1:4] species <- iris[, 5] # carry out the test test1 <- meancov.Test(chart, species) #> H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk, Sigma1 = Sigma2 = ... = Sigmak, k = 3 #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample mean of each group is: #> $setosa #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        5.006        3.428        1.462        0.246  #>  #> $versicolor #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        5.936        2.770        4.260        1.326  #>  #> $virginica #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        6.588        2.974        5.552        2.026  #>  #>  #> The total sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The sample deviation of each group is: #> $setosa #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length       6.0882      4.8616       0.8014      0.5062 #> Sepal.Width        4.8616      7.0408       0.5732      0.4556 #> Petal.Length       0.8014      0.5732       1.4778      0.2974 #> Petal.Width        0.5062      0.4556       0.2974      0.5442 #>  #> $versicolor #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      13.0552       4.174        8.962      2.7332 #> Sepal.Width        4.1740       4.825        4.050      2.0190 #> Petal.Length       8.9620       4.050       10.820      3.5820 #> Petal.Width        2.7332       2.019        3.582      1.9162 #>  #> $virginica #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      19.8128      4.5944      14.8612      2.4056 #> Sepal.Width        4.5944      5.0962       3.4976      2.3338 #> Petal.Length      14.8612      3.4976      14.9248      2.3924 #> Petal.Width        2.4056      2.3338       2.3924      3.6962 #>  #>  #> The sample deviation within group is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      38.9562     13.6300      24.6246      5.6450 #> Sepal.Width       13.6300     16.9620       8.1208      4.8084 #> Petal.Length      24.6246 p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio            1.767862e-155                          #> Likelihood Ratio (Modified) 2.200389e-152                          #> M                            6.984086e+02                          #> Chi2                         6.809880e+02       0 41.3371381514274 #>  #> The degree of freedom of Chi-square statistic is:Chi2( 28 ) #> The Modified factor is: 0.0249433106575964 #> Conclusion: Reject test2 <- meancov.Test(chart, species, detail = FALSE) #> H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk, Sigma1 = Sigma2 = ... = Sigmak, k = 3 #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                                     Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio            1.767862e-155                          #> Likelihood Ratio (Modified) 2.200389e-152                          #> M                            6.984086e+02                          #> Chi2                         6.809880e+02       0 41.3371381514274 #> Conclusion: Reject Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>     5.843333     3.057333     3.758000     1.199333

what: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
text: Test whether covariance matrices multiple multivariate normal populations equal. Suppose k populations, null hypothesis "H0: Sigma1 = Sigma2 = ... = Sigmak".

title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
code: covTest.multi(X, label, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
text: X data matrix matrix data frame. label vector group labels. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMeanT sample mean. SampMeanWithin sample mean group. SdWithin sample deviation group. SdWithinT sample deviation within group. Df degree freedom. sampleSize sample size group. d Modified factor statistic.

title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.88-89.

title: Multiple Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.multi
text: Xifeng Zhang

what: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
text: Test whether covariance matrix equal certain value. null hypothesis "H0: Sigma = Sigma0" "H0: Sigma = sigma^2 * Sigma0".

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
code: covTest.single(data, Sigma0, ball = FALSE, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
text: data data matrix matrix data frame. Sigma0 covariance matrix null hypothesis true. ball boolean value. Default FALSE. FALSE, test whether covariance matrix Sigma0 (known), means null hypothesis "H0: Sigma = Sigma0". TRUE Sigma0 unit matrix, Mauchly's ball test performed. TRUE Sigma0 (known) unit matrix, covariance matrix tested see sigma^2*Sigma0 (sigma^2 unknown), means null hypothesis "H0: Sigma = sigma^2 * Sigma0". alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Return ball FALSE. Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMean sample mean. SampA sample deviation. Df degree freedom. Return ball TRUE Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMean sample mean. SampA sample deviation. sigma.hat estimation sigma^2. Df degree freedom.

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.83-88.

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Single Covariance Matrix Hypothesis Testing — covTest.single
code: data(iris) X <- iris[, 1:4] # carry out the test test1 <- covTest.single(X, diag(1, 4)) #> H0: Sigma = Sigma0 #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                          Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio 3.829315e-223                          #> Chi2              1.024268e+03       0 18.3070380532751 #>  #> The degree of freedom of Chi-square statistic is:Chi2( 10 ) #> Conclusion: Reject test2 <- covTest.single(X, diag(1, 4), ball = TRUE) #> H0: Sigma = sigma^2 * Sigma0 #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The estimation of sigma^2 is: 1.13561766666667 #>  #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                          Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio 8.616505e-321                          #> W                 5.400950e-05                          #> Chi2              1.448568e+03       0 16.9189776046204 #>  #> The degree of freedom of Chi-square statistic is:Chi2( 9 ) #> Conclusion: Reject test3 <- covTest.single(X, diag(2, 4), ball = TRUE) #> H0: Sigma = sigma^2 * Sigma0 #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The estimation of sigma^2 is: 0.567808833333333 #>  #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                          Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio 8.616505e-321                          #> W                 5.400950e-05                          #> Chi2              1.448568e+03       0 16.9189776046204 #>  #> The degree of freedom of Chi-square statistic is:Chi2( 9 ) #> Conclusion: Reject test4 <- covTest.single(X, diag(1, 4), detail = FALSE) #> H0: Sigma = Sigma0 #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                          Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio 3.829315e-223                          #> Chi2              1.024268e+03       0 18.3070380532751 #> Conclusion: Reject # get the elements test1$Stat #>                          Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Likelihood Ratio 3.829315e-223                          #> Chi2              1.024268e+03       0 18.3070380532751 test2$Df #> [1] "Chi2( 9 )" test3$sigma.hat #> [1] 0.5678088

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
text: Test whether set multivariate normal random vectors independent. null hypothesis "H0: random vectors independent ".

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
code: indTest.multi(data, subdim = FALSE, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
text: data data matrix matrix data frame. column represents random variable. subdim dimensions submatrices. default FALSE, means independence components random vector tested. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMean sample mean. SampA sample deviation. SampAii sample deviation submatrices. Df degree freedom. b Modified factor statistic.

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.92-94.

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Multivariate Normal Independence Test — indTest.multi
code: data(iris) chart <- iris[, 1:4] # carry out the test test1 <- indTest.multi(chart) #> H0: The random vectors are independent of each other #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933 statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                          Value p.value  Critical.Value #> V                 8.109611e-03                         #> Likelihood Ratio 1.496239e-157 indTest.multi(chart, subdim = c(2, 1, 1)) #> H0: The random vectors are independent of each other #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The sample deviation of Submatrix is: #> [[1]] #>              Sepal.Length what: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
text: Test whether mean vectors multiple multivariate normal populations equal covariance matrices equal. Suppose k populations, null hypothesis "H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk". two approximations (Bartlett's chi2 Rao's F) compute p-value critical value. realized value Wilks Lambda statistic degrees freedom also provided. want perform exact test, consult Wilks Lambda statistic quantile table , depending realized value statistic degrees freedom.

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
code: meanTest.multi(X, label, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
text: X data matrix matrix data frame. label vector group labels. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMeanT sample mean. SampMeanWithin sample mean group. SdTotal total sample deviation. SdBetween sample deviation group. SdWithin sample deviation group. SdWithinT sample deviation within group. Df degree freedom. sampleSize sample size group.

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.80-83.

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Multiple Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.multi
code: data(iris) chart <- iris[, 1:4] species <- iris[, 5] # carry out the test test1 <- meanTest.multi(chart, species) #> H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk, k = 3 #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample mean within group is: #> $setosa #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        5.006        3.428        1.462        0.246  #>  #> $versicolor #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        5.936        2.770        4.260        1.326  #>  #> $virginica #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>        6.588        2.974        5.552        2.026  #>  #>  #> The total sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The sample deviation between group is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length     63.21213   -19.95267 186.7740    80.41333 #>  #> The sample deviation within group is: #> $setosa #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length       6.0882      4.8616       0.8014 0.5442 #>  #> $versicolor #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      13.0552       4.174        8.962      2.7332 #> Sepal.Width        4.1740       4.825        4.050      2.0190 #> Petal.Length       8.9620       4.050       10.820      3.5820 #> Petal.Width        2.7332       2.019        3.582      1.9162 #>  #> $virginica #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      19.8128      4.5944      14.8612      2.4056 #> Sepal.Width        4.5944      5.0962       3.4976      2.3338 #> Petal.Length      14.8612      3.4976      14.9248      2.3924 #> Petal.Width        2.4056      2.3338       2.3924      3.6962 #>  #>  #> The sample deviation within group (total) is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length      38.9562     13.6300      24.6246      5.6450 #> Sepal.Width       13.6300     16.9620       8.1208      4.8084 #> Petal.Length      24.6246      8.1208      27.2226      6.2718 #> Petal.Width        5.6450      4.8084       6.2718      6.1566 #>  #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                        Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Wilks Lambda    2.343863e-02                          #> Bartlett's Chi2 5.461153e+02       0 15.5073130558655 #> Rao's F         1.274530e+04       0  1.9706194163219 #>  #> The degree of freedom is: #>                                    df #> Wilks Lambda    Lambda( 4 , 147 , 2 ) #> Bartlett's Chi2             Chi2( 8 ) #> Rao's F                  F( 8 , 288 ) #>  #> Conclusion: Bartlett's Chi-square:  Reject ; Rao's F:  Reject test2 <- meanTest.multi(chart, species, detail = FALSE) #> H0: mu1 = mu2 = ... = muk, k = 3 #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                        Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Wilks Lambda    2.343863e-02                          #> Bartlett's Chi2 5.461153e+02       0 15.5073130558655 #> Rao's F         1.274530e+04       0  1.9706194163219 #>  #> Conclusion: Bartlett's Chi-square:  Reject ; Rao's F:  Reject # get the elements test1$Stat #>                        Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Wilks Lambda    2.343863e-02                          #> Bartlett's Chi2 5.461153e+02       0 15.5073130558655 #> Rao's F         1.274530e+04       0  1.9706194163219 test1$SampMeanT #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>     5.843333     3.057333     3.758000     1.199333  test1$sampleSize #>     setosa versicolor  virginica  #>         50         50         50

what: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
text: Test whether mean vector single multivariate normal population equal certain value population covariance matrix known unknown. null hypothesis "H0: mu = mu0".

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
code: meanTest.single(data, mu0, Sigma0 = FALSE, alpha = 0.05, detail = TRUE)

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
text: data data matrix matrix data frame. mu0 mean vector null hypothesis true. Sigma0 population covariance matrix. Default FALSE means covariance matrix unknown. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMean sample mean. SampA sample deviation. Df degree freedom.

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.66-68.

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Single Mean Vector Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.single
code: data(iris) X <- iris[, 1:4] mu0 <- c(5.8, 3.0, 4.3, 1.3) # carry out the test test1 <- meanTest.single(X, mu0) #> H0: mu = (5.8, 3, 4.3, 1.3)' when Sigma is unknown #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 #>  #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                  Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Hotelling T2 244.22150                          #> F             59.82607       0 2.43363344771214 #>  #> The degree of freedom is: #>                         df #> Hotelling T2 T2( 4 , 149 ) #> F             F( 4 , 146 ) #>  #> Conclusion: Reject test2 <- meanTest.single(X, mu0, Sigma0 = diag(1, 4)) #> H0: mu = (5.8, 3, 4.3, 1.3)' when Sigma is known #> The sample mean is: (5.84333.05733.7581.1993)' #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>        Value      p.value Critical.Value #> Chi2 46.3594 2.073171e-09       9.487729 #>  #> The degree of Chi-square is: 4 #> Conclusion: Reject test3 <- meanTest.single(X, mu0, detail = FALSE) #> H0: mu = (5.8, 3, 4.3, 1.3)' when Sigma is unknown #> The statistics, p value and critical value are: #>                  Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Hotelling T2 244.22150                          #> F             59.82607       0 2.43363344771214 #> Conclusion: Reject # get the elements test1$Stat #>                  Value p.value   Critical.Value #> Hotelling T2 244.22150                          #> F             59.82607       0 2.43363344771214 test1$SampMean #> Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width Petal.Length  Petal.Width  #>     5.843333     3.057333     3.758000     1.199333  test1$SampA #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   102.168333   -6.322667     189.8730    76.92433 #> Sepal.Width     -6.322667   28.306933     -49.1188   -18.12427 #> Petal.Length   189.873000  -49.118800     464.3254   193.04580 #> Petal.Width     76.924333  -18.124267     193.0458    86.56993 test1$Df #>                         df #> Hotelling T2 T2( 4 , 149 ) #> F             F( 4 , 146 )

what: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
text: Test whether mean vectors two multivariate normal populations equal covariance matrices equal unequal. null hypothesis "H0: mu1 = mu2".

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
code: meanTest.two(   data1,   data2,   alpha = 0.05,   equal = TRUE,   method = c("None", "Coupled", "Transformed"),   detail = TRUE )

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
text: data1 matrix data frame group 1. data2 matrix data frame group 2. alpha significance level. Default 0.05. equal boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, covariance matrix equal. FALSE, covariance matrix equal. method string value. Default "None". equal FALSE, must choose method "Coupled" "Transformed". Choose "Coupled" sample size two groups equal. Choose "Transformed" sample size two groups equal. detail boolean value. Default TRUE. TRUE, detail test result displayed. FALSE, simple summary displayed.

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
text: object class "testResult", list following elements: Return param equal TRUE. Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMean1 sample mean group 1. SampMean2 sample mean group 2. SampA1 sample deviation group 1. SampA2 sample deviation group 2. MixSampA mixed sample deviation. Df degree freedom. Return param equal FALSE method "Coupled". Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMeanC sample mean coupled data. SampAC sample deviation coupled data. Df degree freedom. dataC coupled data. Return param equal FALSE method "Transformed". Conclusion conclusion test. Stat data frame containing statistics, p value critical value. SampMeanT sample mean transformed data. SampAT sample deviation transformed data. Df degree freedom. dataT transformed data. Return param equal FALSE method "Transformed".

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
text: Huixuan, Gao. Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. Peking University Press, 2005: pp.76-80.

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
text: Xifeng Zhang

title: Two Mean Vectors Hypothesis Testing — meanTest.two
code: data(iris) X <- iris[1:50, 1:4] Y <- iris[51:100, 1:4] # carry out the test test1 <- meanTest.two(X, Y) #> H0: mu1 = mu2 with unknown but equal covariance matrix #> The sample mean of group 1 is: (5.0063.4281.4620.246)' #> The sample deviation of group 1 is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length       6.0882      4.8616       0.8014      0.5062 2.46749362344965 #>  #> The degree of freedom is: #>                      df #> Hotelling T2 T2( 4 98 ) #> F             F( 4 95 ) #>  #> Conclusion: Reject test2 <- meanTest.two(X, Y, detail = TRUE) Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length       6.0882      4.8616       0.8014      0.5062 #> Sepal.Width        4.8616      7.0408       0.5732      0.4556 #> Petal.Length       0.8014      0.5732       1.4778      0.2974 #> Petal.Width        0.5062      0.4556       0.2974      0.5442 #>  #> The sample mean of group 2 is: (5.9362.774.261.326)' #> The sample deviation of group 2 is: #> Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length   0.19534082  0.09220000   0.09962653  0.03305510 #> Sepal.Width    0.09220000  0.12107959   0.04717551  0.02525102 #> Petal.Length   0.09962653  0.04717551 (-0.930.658-2.798-1.08)' #> The coupled sample deviation is: #>              Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #> Sepal.Length       20.585      9.9570      10.9730       3.200 #>
